Yvjt3-coGyFA_LG0xinPIA.text: A great place to get your bike repaired.Ask for Sam or Nikki. They have always given me good service and honest assessments.I trust them with my bikes - and my life depends on them when you cycle in Central London !!!. You need a second mortgage to buy a coffee though; and eating there requires the debt of a medium-sized third world country - there are plenty of cheaper places nearby.

fjNlXgpwsYQhLUhrMko-HA.text: Seems like a nice rustic place and the food looked very nice, however, due to my current diet, I was unfortunately only there for the coffee, the coffee was OK, a bit burnt/bitter, but that could be the roast, but that's what I'm basing my review on, and the staff were OK, think maybe they're more friendly if you're a regular and/or have a bike.

cei0F2iAstRnSq9f8tWzFw.text: It is also a great place to study, this cafe served a remarkable coffee,and has the perfect environment to meet up with friends, reading books, orsurfing on the internet because they have free Wi-Fi.

edZSRGsCF0NV73m36Fehgg.text: So. Fucking. Hip.Combining two enterprises known for their overwhelmingly snobby clientele - coffee and cycling - you'd think Look Mum No Hands would be insufferable. And in some ways you'd be right.Nevertheless, as both a lover of coffee and a cyclist*, I can't help but appreciate what they're doing here. However, the less-than-friendly counter service** and the rather pedestrian third-wave brew are inexcusable. ________________________________*I am insufferable.**Leave the snobbery to me, kthx.

XC8tbQI1Jl4aylhY9c4DqQ.text: So there's a lot of love for the cafe part of Look Mum No Hands. But what about the bike shop bit? Definitely the best service I've received on my Dutch bike. The fact that they even embraced my Dutch bike with such enthusiasm after it was damaged in a crash is laudable: various other bike shops shied away from helping after learning that my bike was a chain case-equipped, everything-internal Dutch bike. That LMNH then proceeded to do a perfect job, getting everything right first time (servicing the gears, brakes, installing a new fork and handlebars) is an unheard of experience for me in the two years I've had my Dutch bike. It was also remarkably good value: just £20 for a basic service and £45 to install a new fork and handlebars (purely labour: I supplied the new parts).As for the cafe bit of LMNH, I can see why it's so adored: loads of space and seating, large windows through which plenty of natural light streams through, free wifi and mains sockets everywhere - this is a very pleasant place to setup with a laptop. The crowd is a pleasant mix of cyclists and hipsters, the latter offering excellent people-watching potential.I don't think cafe is perfect: the service, though friendly, can be a little too laid back sometimes; the food prices are I think slightly on the high side; I was slightly underwhelmed by the coffee, which seemed a little weak (next time I'll try a stronger one). Still, the abundance of natural light, friendly service, great atmosphere supportive of cyclists of all denominations and unusually good bike service makes it clear 5 star material. Even though it's on the wrong side of London for me, it's unquestionably where I'll be heading the next time my bike needs a service.

I0Bh3Jydu8LFQHcj7wtWKg.text: I'm no cycling expert, but as far as cafes go, this one is a bit over-hyped. I visited hoping to study and caffeinate, but it seemed like half of Shoreditch had the same idea. While the inside is fairly large (and neatly decorated), seating is limited, especially near plug outlets, and the noise level is quite loud.My latte was good -- strong, foamy, and neatly presented (albeit more expensive than comparable shops). I only stayed for one cup, before finding a different, more comfortable, less crowded study spot.

4R__KgP5hGmxiR-I6b45JQ.text: Get your bike serviced while you nosh!  So basically, it's a cafe, a place to get your bike serviced a place to buy bicycle bits and bobs and its all very cool.  They'll lend you a lock if you want to lock up your bike while you eat inside, they have an outside terrace and the whole place is massively cool.  It's sort of a small warehouse that has been converted, there are a lot of magazines around, a butler sink with glasses and a tap for your water and simple tables and benches.  The menu is based around salads and pies so that's something for everyone for a start!    Go if you are in the area, doubly so if you're on a bike.

8m4qYrgo5yZP5gESkvQ63A.text: lookmumnohands.comTake your bike out for a cup of tea and some cake

kiitpjCriB9XS1mu9jkeXA.text: Haiku for LMNHSunshine, snacks, and JoeI can pump air in my wheelsThey have lots of plugs

OpsXf10mh4R7n-yu_IgA5g.text: Love it!  I absolutely love the concept of this place.  For those who are not mechanically inclined, go get your bike fixed, and while you're waiting grab a sandwich/pastry/drink.  If you are mechanically inclined, they have a tool chest for you to work with.If you are somewhere in the middle, you can grab a beer when you get frustrated with attempting to fix your bike.Either way, the staff is super friendly and happy to help if you need to tinker, fix a flat or just want to hang out.They have free wireless, which makes it even better!

m2uLB3hxMyYeWtjpr5GfuA.text: Is it a café? Is it a bike shop? No, it's both!You're just as likely to see someone sipping on an organic peppermint tea as an employee rolling around on someone's just-repaired bicycle. A tire pump sits outside while eager diners crowd the sunlit interior.Be sure to take a peep at the various crafty goods. I was quite tempted by the nifty reflective buttons. After all, one can never glitter too much on a dark and twisted street at night...NB: Ask the barista for the temporary wi-fi password. Reportedly, it changes on a regular basis.

0OTslPzydJzjy_th1o3eKQ.text: I love this coffee place, even though I don't own a bike. The place is awash with lovely energy, great coffee and is the perfect place to people watch and perv on bikes. (Or in my case the people with the bikes)

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom

9tx3PzupXrnvL4iryQBraQ.text: Very good coffee, first time ive had a chai latte, and it was amazing. Although wasnt expecting the minimum charge on card of £5... And also the redonkulous price for a bottle of beer, (£6.00 if i remember correctly) although to be fair it was a big bottle, about half a litre. Im just a broke ass student looking for a place to do my dissertation!Great atmosphere, lively but chilled out enough to get some work done. A little thing to note however, the wifi. The wifi is unforgiving when it comes to throttling (for any non-tech heads, its when you use too much internet that it caps your speed). I found i was unable to listen to 8tracks, youtube or last.fm whilst browsing without getting throttled, it was fairly crowded however, but i still felt this shouldnt happen!Other things id like to elaborate on but too tired to articulate would be:- Loads of power sockets on benches- Its a bike shop- bus stop right outside

0Tu_vu5dcnmZES-izMRBBQ.text: Came here after work with a friend for a quick coffee (even though I didn't have a bike!)The lattes are good and they do a scrumptious chelsea bun! It has a typical East-London vibe. It's great but I probably wouldn't go out of my way to come here again if I'm honest!

y4pNMUXO3z2V_s41II4tfQ.text: Any place that serves a decent iced coffee is a place after my heart. A good iced coffee is hard to find (I'm looking at you Costa!) in London. It wasn't hot coffee served over coffee (so so wrong). This place served it up big and cold and delicious.I love the quirkiness here too. They sell items for cyclists and have a few long racks for cyclists to put their bikes. Great touches like this make this place a winner.I have to go back and try their food. It looked quite tasty.

iswUNcM251jaEa2rbsj7pA.text: Really fun place for fast breakfast! Museli is incredible, coffees are perfectly acceptable, if clumsily put together. Walnut cake is very solid.I love the bike shop vibe, and the decade old racing bikes of early-era carbon fiber are always fun to stare at - far more interesting than the endless ss skinny-steel rigs one sees in mass further east.

5jd_Ur3rb6GSZ_tTbtXsDg.text: I would have really liked this place if not for the rude employees.  Would it kill you to say hello and smile?Otherwise, good coffee and food and nice atmosphere.

mST0mbwRNbj3r9xHiobySg.text: An unusual and very nice place to spend some time. As far as I remember, they offer free wifi, and even if not, they at least have plenty of plugs, something I missed at many places while I lived at a hostel and sometimes wanted to do some stuff somewhere in town.Definitely a recommendation!

98tnXsr145Y2cG4thMrB6g.text: Come find me, I'm on 29th and Hawthorne. No, I'm on 47th and Stark. Er, wait, maybe I'm on Belmont near 33rd. 38th and Gladstone. 35th and Powell. Ok... I'm definitely in Portland. Somewhere on the East side. Of... Er... London? Yes. I'm in London. You'll relate and relish in my locational confusion when I explain that Look Mum No Hands! is a bike workshop and café bar for London's (no, not Portland's) cyclists, cycle sport fans, and nature loving, caffeine addicted, dog walking, organic health nuts of the world. Ok, so I added that last part, but with luxury homemade muesli, local beers, daily homemade pastries, freshly made salads, a deadly pull of espresso and super fast free wifi, it goes without saying. Oh and it's dog friendly. ...Cause, well, of course it is. As I'm sitting and sipping and browsing, I'm listening to Jackson. "We got married in a fever!" Seriously. Am I reeeeally in London? If so, please please please never leave me. I'll be a permanent fixture here if you'll have me.

MSnPuqwsf6i7OnsE-Pn_lA.text: Brilliant breakfasts, the coffee is teeters between acceptable and okay, but the the POWER ALL ALONG THE WALL is GREAT - I have spent a lot of time programming here and while the wifi can be a bit patchy who doesn't carry 3G dongles with them? Probably the least happy baristas in the area sadly - CHEER UP GUYS AND SMILE MORE.

QQiEKuqD9zzx1F-RhzPChg.text: Trying to mix shop and coffee need to be done well; it is not easy and of course this place doesn't get it.Irritating stuff. Looks like dirty.Expensive.

cpm8VWVabfS2O_1QrwKVWw.text: + good coffee+ free wifi+ power sockets to recharge your gadgets+ bike repairs!+ chilled out serviceIt's a great spot for catching up with friends, on emails, do a bit of programming, AND get your bikes fixed if you are so inclined. Food is a little pricey but smelled and looked good, and they have nice coffees. It's a really chilled out place where you can stay a little longer (because you are plugged in to the mains and not running low on battery) and don't get any evil stares while using their free wifi to catch up on a bit of work. There's also some seating outside to soak up the sun while you eat and work. Great little cafe!

qoRn3Mp14w906EMyz-6b9Q.text: Super hipster. A little dirty. Food oily. Wifi slow.

Y5cfK6BksTnWWQFGar-I1A.text: New to London and dying to find a place that opens later than 6pm to do some work.I am in love with this place as they open till late and let you work with your laptop here.  Not to mention to concept and the decor of the cafe is extremely attracting. Staff are friendly and they have free wifi.  Have been here twice after work and there are quite a few people with laptop sitting there for hours, from the looks of it this is also a nerdy place where the coders and developers like to hang out!The food and the coffee are okay, wouldn't say it's the best but the rest of the pros outweighed them :)One thing to note is that they don't allow you to use laptops during lunch.

J4aALheTzkijqs31tIqCSg.text: Perhaps, like me, you are regretting not filling your tubes with more air and wish there was a coffee shop with delicious drinks and food where you could find a pump. Doubling as a bike shop, this amazing spot is exactly what you need. Been wanting to try them since they sold me a Kernel IPA by Waterloo Bridge last summer. Thanks to the second transit strike this year, I rode my bike home from work and, just as I was getting tired, passed by this urban oasis for cyclists. Could not have been better timed. Try their smoothies, shakes, pastries, coffee, or great beer while your bike gets serviced, or just to have a quick rest. Perhaps the most cycle-friendly cafe in town. Maybe because it's such a nice day, I'm having a hard time leaving the outside seating space, especially since I can keep an eye on my bike. However it is 6pm and a huge crowd is gathering, which is another good sign, I suppose. If places like these were more common, I'd ditch my Oyster card immediately. Perhaps I will just so I can ride by it each afternoon. In any event, hoping to be back soon.

qR0-Nyfs-nCSq1FWaKstLQ.text: This place is super popular for a reason. Really good and healthy (if you want something healthy) cafe food, almost always room to sit (it's pretty big), working WiFi, nice fixtures and decor. A really good place to sit and work or meet friends.

ERCzRTE_nRQnKM73Zznw0A.text: Amazing coffee shop with great coffees - and they also repair your bike! Walls hung with cycle gear, space to lock up outside and cycle races occasionally on the TV. Excellent sweets and cakes to put those calories back in, and amazing pies. £8.50 gets you a hot pie and three salads to fill up that hangover. Collect your own cutlery and sit outside in summer.

xwmKU_5249ITpK5mRWPPMA.text: I work around the corner from Look Mum No Hands, and if I weren't trying to reduce my expenditures on coffee, I would come here everyday. They serve excellent Americanos, and in the summer, their blended coffee drinks are close to perfection. They use powder instead of syrup in their blended drinks, which improves the consistency. They are also not excessively sweet, which is a rarity in the world of blended iced coffee drinks.In addition to their superb coffee, LMNH serves the freshest tasting soups and salads in the area. Their sweet potato, coconut and coriander soup is addictive and is better than anything served at the nearby Nusa. They offer a variety of fresh salads using seasonal ingredients as well.The only reason I am not giving this place five stars is because occasionally when you order a mixed salad, they give you different salads than they display in the glass cases, which is misleading. Once I ended up with a salad plate consisting mainly of creamy potato salad (which I despise) and pesto pasta, with no sign of the fresh-looking shredded beetroot or jerusalem artichoke salads that were calling to me from the glass cases when I placed the order. They should be upfront about what a mixed salad box consists of each day.All in all, this is a wonderful place to stop by for a coffee and a cake, or a soup or salad and a glass of wine or bottle of beer. On a sunny day, their outdoor patio is a peaceful place to spend the afternoon.

8fvxlJc-xrnC2lXMYbO55A.text: A great place to grab a coffee and chat, it's airy and cheap.It's a little Shoreditch if that bothers you but lovely and relaxed :)

0d_hJRvq9ry0jgqWmOAx7w.text: Love this coffee shop! Favorite in London so far. Great Americano, plenty of practical seating, bright and lively decor. I came for breakfast (fruit and yogurt - plentiful portion) and next time I'll have to come to just work for the day. The pastries and baked goods looked DELICIOUS. Standard artisan/hip coffee shop prices. Not too bad.

5xhzb9OjGXb6CSiu7y8njw.text: Now reviewing this as an actual bike owner, I came in here when Tinker (my bike) was feeling a little under the weather. Her back tire was in serious need of air and it was slowing me down on the street of London. As I can in, the very helpful lady have a quick look and then pointed me in the direction of the pump. After explaining that I didn't have a clue what I was doing, she kindly showed me, without making me like I'm an idiot who shouldn't own a bike and then let me do it myself.I left in 10 minutes with a happy bike and it didn't cost me a penny. Thank Mum You're Great!

di-ToBBNhNrZSP7XWzZZrQ.text: This bicycle-repair-cum-coffee-shop has clearly filled a gaping hole in the lives of Londoners. I've been here on several Saturdays to find the place packed with cyclists. Cyclists in special cycling shoesCyclists drinking boozeCyclists watching the Tour de France raceCyclists all over the placeThe wifi doesn't work very well at the outside tables so if you need some internets work inside.Expect equal amounts of skinny jeans and lycra short pants.Warning: Hanging out here could induce serious velo-envy.

yM6RfGMwKJZfvlzKJFKS-Q.text: As I frantically looked for internet access here in London in order to keep connected to those I love at home and the world in general, I find that Mum's is the best place to be. It's spacious and inviting, both day and night. During the daytime and in good weather, the large doors open up allowing the fresh air and abundant light to poor in. At night, candles are lit and music plays softly. I grab my freshly squeezed orange juice, daily, on my way back from getting some mighty good toast down the way and return at night for some tea or coffee with friends. Mum's has a great mix of people, and everyone is so so so nice. Free wifi and the whole bike concept makes this place one of my faves so far. I'm gonna look for a bike next week. =)

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Front counter area.
Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Side windows.
Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Back lounge area. Outlets plentiful.

Gy8NrGf2V4yUsOLZEBKvFA.text: This cafe reminds me of home...  Wide windows, large wooden tables, bikes hanging on the walks... this is definitely a transplant from Abbot Kinney!  A great place to study, this cafe has amazing coffee, and has the perfect ambiance to catch up with friends, read a book, or do some work on your laptop!  There's free wifi :]There are outlets near the back of the cafe, as well as cushy couches and sofas to relax on.  You can choose from yummy looking pastries, or sandwiches and soups that are reasonably priced!  It feels really cozy yet spacious here with plenty of tables, and the people who work here are extremely friendly!  If you come during earlier times (before 12pm), you can settle down for some quiet reading.  But once it hits lunch, it gets really busy and can get quite loud!  It also doubles as a bike shop... how awesome is that?!?!

D4LXD8yOC3WlV0AztCZ8IQ.text: It is very hard not to love LMNH.  The cafe is light, seats are plentiful, WiFi is free and the welcome is warm.  For me, it is generally a breakfast destination and, after a morning cycling, LMNH's muesli which is packed full of fruit and nuts never fails to disappoint. I like to think that it is healthy but I don't really care when it tastes this good.  The coffee is not quite up to the standards of London's best but is perfectly serviceable. During le Tour, LMNH shows the stages live on a drop down TV.  It must be the only place in London to do so.  Grabbing a beer watching cycling's legends power up alpine slopes makes me feel slightly guilty.  However, save for being road side, I can't think of a better place to watch the action unfold.

rCTNLWHT-UQXeyt8kwRasw.text: How come they weren't around when I needed them most...like when I was writing my dissertation last year!Those who know me, know that I'm a sucker for good coffee shops and I basically treat them as my cubicle-on-the-go. I don't know, I was never a person who could work well in a quiet place...like for example a library. Here's the thing with libraries: when I'm in a library, I expect people to be quiet...and I get very irritated when people do otherwise. In fact, it totally wrecks my concentration when people whisper around me, because all I can concentrate on is whether I want to tell them to shut up or not and punch their face!On the other hand, I expect a coffee shop to be lively and so I don't mind people chit-chatting around me...quite the opposite; it has an invigorating effect on me! Anyway, what's that got to do with "Look Mum No Hands"? - Everything...this place would have been among my favourite study places if I were still a student: lot's of tables, plenty of outlets, free wifi, lots of day-light, friendly staff...a real cubicle-on-the-go! On top of that, I love the idea of combining a bike shop with a coffee shop; in fact, I believe that bikers are the Bohemians of the 21st century and so it only makes sense for them to hang out here.Plus, the coffee was really tasty, which is always a plus for a coffee shop, right?

Yfa0DDGatB1BxkPhivWHUw.text: They need more space and on cold days the door stays open. Its an okay concept but the exterior and decoration are nice.

Ve-JAyEYqcBNcUMQYPPYdA.text: Top class. Really cool design and nice atmosphere.

dbva2Zp2dxY_Pc5xvwXK2Q.text: Study spot requirements:Plentiful seating: I want to say this place has the best seating out of any London cafe I've visited to date.  There are multiple tables outside for good weather (and there are outlets outside, too!!!) and there are maybe a dozen tables inside, along with a bar along the window (so peaceful and out of the way as opposed to next to the register) and also a big, V shaped bench in the corner.  Oh, and there are copious amounts of outlets everywhere!Locally owned: Yes, and by enthusiastic, quirky folks.Relaxed atmosphere: Toootally.  There was a bit of a lunch rush (of which we caught the tail end) but outside of 12-2 (and maybe dinner time), it's pretty laid back. It's not the cleanest (the cushions on the V bench are worse for wear) but it also feels a bit like a workshop, so the worn-in feeling fits.  Plus, it makes it feel so informal and comfy.Quality coffee: Yeah!  And a few good teas, too.  Plus, kindly, they bring your drinks to you and bus dishes often.Snacks: I had a jacket potato, because it was rainy and it felt right, but it was really an incredibly uninventive choice, given the pies and salads and specials and stuff. And they have daily specials (and lots of vegetarian options).  They also had some interesting cakes (or non-cakes, like the green olive twist thing my friend got). Price: Normal, £2-3 range for drinks, and you can grab lunch for about £5Wi-fi: Free, fast, and long lasting with all of those outlets!Truthfully, I didn't sense or notice any kind of bike-shop stuff going on.  I also wasn't looking.  We did sit here for four hours, though, over three rounds of drinks, and it was totally easy to hunker down and get some work done.

alqadoijOQZ74XydhIqHvA.text: Great place. Delicious food, free wifi, bike repairs and a buzzy atmosphere. What's not to like!

uo1TYHKWCd64TQkBTzK8IA.text: This is an all-around fabulous coffee/bike shop with yummy eats, cool vibe, and impressive space (for London, that is!). After several visits, I've found that the flat whites can be hit-or-miss depending on the barista, but in general, it's decent. I haven't gone for the bike service because I don't own a bike, but it seems like a neat place for cyclists to not only get their bikes serviced but also to congregate for regular cycle rides through the city.NOW. Onto the really important thing: the GUINNESS CHOCOLATE CAKE. I've had quite a few versions of a guinness chocolate cake and LMNH has, hands down, THE best one. I don't know what they put in it, but the flavour fills your senses with the divine mix of guinness and chocolate. The texture is moist, and there's always the right amount of cream. Just writing about it makes my mouth water and my craving shoot of the wazoo.OK, calming down now. The other cakes are actually very good as well, so even if they didn't have the guinness chocolate cake there, you'll have other great options. I am intending to try the food some time, especially since their selection of drinks is pretty attractive. Fab place to relax, work, or meet up with friends - definitely recommend! (especially a certain cake of theirs...)

LuH1RZMlHRCqNhfrBrt5tg.text: Another great pit stop for those of you brave enough to take on the cars & buses of the city on two wheels.   LMNH has a couple of locations around East London, but this smaller cafe is probably one of my favorites. They have a mini bike-hospital attached just to the side of the cafe entrance should you have any malfunctions you need looking at. The food is great, with a selection of cakes, pastries, salads and yummy hot food (great for breakfast) - they do a mean cup of coffee and offer cool cycling related events and workshops too.

pmf_F0l5E0aYQ9U_-qYiEQ.text: Out of all the London coffee shops I've visited, LMNH is by far my favorite.LMNH is a coffee shop/bike co-op that offers delicious meals, snacks, and other goodies. As soon as you walk in, you are surrounded by a range of bicycle accessories and supplies they sell; if I were a cyclist, I would definitely make this part of my daily route.During my visit, I ordered an Earle Gray tea and a raspberry tart. The tea came with it's own pot and a side of milk. I really enjoyed the tea, however they make it a tad stronger than what I am used to. I asked the gentleman behind the counter what pastry he would recommend and he asked me a series of questions which resulted in me ordering the raspberry tart. I would definitely recommend it!I love the amble seating, natural lighting, and friendly service. I saw many people enjoying breakfast entrees, so the next time I'm in town, I am definitely making this my breakfast spot! I brought a book with me during my last visit, but I can see myself doing work or meeting a friend up for coffee/tea.

RjV-rdsy4TqTBprYDeJ-8g.text: Ah what can I say. Mostly, they took care of my bike and got it back to me in great condition. Labour was less than I thought it would be as well! I wouldn't hesitate to bring my bike back there anytime. The food and coffee is decent, but somewhat expensive.

D1Ev445ka9TzAlEm0tEhBg.text: Have to say this place was a huge disappointment. The place looked busy but what place doesn't that offers free Wi Fi? Switch it off and people melt away.Its hugely important to remember that the prices that LMNH are charging reflect more what they can get away with rather than the quality of what's being served. Too many coffee shops see the amount of froth they give on a latte as a good way of enhancing their profit margins. Considering the small size of the cup LMNH uses the amount of froth served means that the actual amount of coffee you get is pitifully small for just shy of £3. I was also surprised to note that the coffee wasn't anywhere close to being 'hot'. Given the choice I'd have a Starbucks 'Clover' over this any day.My mate a non-coffee drinker (I know I know) had a hot (supposedly) Chocolate. lets just say you wouldn't want to be serving this to the kids as they'd bouncing off the walls for days judging by the sweetness. Again it would be perfectly possible to sell a quality hot chocolate for the price and size LMNH serve but nowhere near as profitable.Didn't have time to get any food but the prices looked off putting. In fairness the salad did look a good size.If I had to sum up LMNH it would be "All mouth and no trousers" or "Look! The Emporer has no clothes on!" Others might look the other way when it comes to quality because it's 'trendy' but I don't and won't!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Just about tells you everything you need to know about this place and NOT in a good way!

JVwjEfqbyEM9PGywUH23Ow.text: Nice place to get some work done. Very cool vibe with all of the bikes and bike equipment hanging up.I ordered some yogurt with granola and fruit and a latte. It took surprisingly long, although I appreciated that the yogurt parfait wasn't already premade. I really enjoyed the latte. I went around 9 am on a Thursday. The staff seemed overworked and weren't friendly.

BLIDCeHfIuer4ReFstuhWw.text: Where cyclists come to rid themselves of the gear they just had to have 3 months ago when the TdF was going on... I'm being serious, I have been found guilty of this very crime and come on a Sunday to pedal my wares in order to pay for my next bicycle part upgrade.  The coffee here is great and during the TdF it's an amazing place to hang out and share a big table with strangers who all love cycling as much as you do as the cafe will put coverage up on a big screen. You don't have to feel like a geek for wearing your yellow jersey here, we've all got one and we'll be out in full force to greet you!Can be absolutely filled to the brim though, so beware.

tkhHyEhMtMd9g4gXZ2tESg.text: This is a cute little cafe that is a great study spot. The decor of this place is so cute, and there are plenty of tables and a bar space to get some work done. The wifi is really fast, and the coffee and snacks here are very tasty. My roommate always orders the chocolate tea, while I always order a different kind of pastry. The chocolate cake is really good and I would definitely recommend it to chocolate lovers. The lemon and Rosemary cake is also very good. The staff is always friendly here and tries to give you recommendations.

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate cake and lemon and Rosemary cake

NpFHplpN9GYyVvSyZh_Paw.text: This place has great atmosphere and good coffee. It's nice to sit out for brunch on the weekend and tends to attract a very chilled out crowd. Removed a star because the food can be a bit hit-and-miss. Great smoothies though.

ZAomFu6khEzxMqLvAxG-GQ.text: Pretty much as described really - part bike shop, part coffee shop. It has a nice bustling bikey feel. There was a projector showing some sort of biking event on it, and loads of cool bike themed artwork (a cat delivering pizza on a bike, a bike wheel with some other stuff around it)A reasonable amount of outdoor seating but the weather outside was pretty grim. Good amount of indoor seating too. Tiny bit cramped but it beats not getting a seat I guess. Order at the counter and they deliver to your table. Really enjoyed my coffee, but wouldn't go back in a hurry somehow. It's really cool but like a few others, I prefer Timberyard which is right next door.

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Really good effort though I fear he's not getting it back

7yTV0MQRn-F4XjrTCWihig.text: I've seen this is various cycling mags,it certainly didn't disappoint. The food and coffee was excellent, service with a smile. The place has a great atmosphere and overloads the senses with all sorts of wacky and interesting stuff and cycling paraphernalia. Apparently they opened another one somewhere.Worth a visit !

25jFnlNl40bGte8YjqXf6g.text: Bicycle! A machine that holds social, political and aesthetic value. Some people would give up their laptops for their bicycles. Bicycle with coffee - for those who refuse to give up either.Look Mum No Hands! has an air pump, which was my primary source of tire inflating when I was biking from Hackney to Bloomsbury and back-ney.I am cool with the bicycle punk aesthetic of Look Mum No Hands. It has plenty of tables and comfy places to lounge during the day. I wish something like this existed in any other city I have been to. It is frankly, quite brilliant. There are a lot of tires hanging from the ceiling. There is a poster with a 70s sexy bicycle woman with a round booty wearing a g-string next to the toilet.I really like this place. BUT:......55 pence to substitute soya milk instead of cow? This is about 90 cents for a milk substitution in USD. The eco-friendly implications of bicycle riding mars the gross overcharge of eco-friendlier means of milk drinking. Cow causes more carbon emissions than any other milk source. Grazing cows release more gas from digesting the wheat it eats.Britain seems in general to be a lot more friendly when it comes to not charging for soya milk. Brick Lane Coffee does not charge. A handful of others don't either. Some charge 30p, or less. I'm seriously glad I like your loose leaf teas enough to disregard getting any kind of latte or hot chocolate, with soya.I really wouldn't mention the soya charge if I thought Look Mum No Hands! was lame enough not to care. Consider dropping the soya charge all together. An extra 55p translates to not very cool.

LqwlILVZqTtDQU7Oi5szAQ.text: This place is a star among the London coffee scene. And that's probably the main issue. They are so famous and successful that they don't seem to care about the customer service nor the quality anymore.  Ok, it's a nice concept (although not so original these days), the settings are impressive and their coffee cups are funky.  And that's all !  When I came there to try the "institution", I asked the guy at the counter "What's a Chelsea Bun ?" The answer with a rude tone was "It's dough !" Well thank you and sorry for not having a doctorate in english historical pastries but can you try at least not to be so arrogant with customers please ?  Because next time you come to Belgium and ask "What's a stoemp ?", I hope someone answers you "It's food !"  Look Mum No Friends !  Trying to forget the silly answer, I've ordered a egg benedict and a long black. The egg was overcooked : the yolk inside was hard and dry, when it's supposed to be melting. So far, it's the first and only place in the whole London that screwed up a poached egg. Coffee was alright. Fortunately...   Look Mum No Food !   Then, there is this sort of weird vibe around, especially if you are not a cyclist. I mean, almost everyone there is a tatooed grungy hipster in total bike gear, like they were about to climb the Mont-Ventoux. And it's also the headquarter of the Deliveroo guys between two sushi missions. So if you are a pedestrian without any tatoo and no purple hair, you almost feel like you're not in the right place. You don't fit the scenery.   Look Mum no Pedestrian !  And finally, there is the "no laptop policy" on almost every table, which once again doesn't help to make you feel comfortable or welcomed, whether you were about to pretend to work on your Mac or not.  Look Mum No Laptop !  In the end, the general feeling I had with my "LMNH experience" was that you should thank them to tolerate you and give you the extraordinary perk of being one of their grateful customers, especially if you're bikeless..   Will you go back again, son ? Look Mum No Way !

zCbmX4cc3VkbJjKqTqXF9g.text: Half bike shop/half cafe space, it's an interesting concept that you'd expect in Shoreditch. With the doors open, it was a little chilly. The main negative was that I was there for the dreaded no food 30 minutes, between 11 and 11:30. They still have some sad looking cakes and loaf slices, but that's it for food. So I ended up with a smoothie, which was tasty and pretty decently sized for the price.

cAPoNzGww5zmJIXXKTaF-A.text: This cafe/bike repair shop has plenty of seating: a definite plus. It, of course, has wifi which is really a must in any cafe these days. The best thing about this place is that it has a bar top area that has a good number of outlets underneath so you don't have to worry about finding a place to plug in your laptop, tablet, etc.I ordered a hot chocolate--it was more like a luke warm chocolate but the foam art on top was really cute. I also ordered a slice of one of the breads. I think it was banana but can't remember, that's how memorable it was. Whatever it was, it was definitely on the dry side. What was worse is that it came in a plate with dish washing powder still on it...not really that appetizing. I would come back for the wifi and power outlets but skip any drinks or food...so, really--why go back.

IKeEMwNrH1k8tuCcysyh1w.text: Really good to find a good coffee in London!! I really recommend this place.Very Original place in term of ambiance

ELCYXZD-RCu2FG8ccJmi8Q.text: Came here to study with a friend... on the plus side seating and outlets were easy to find and wifi was free. The best part was they let dogs in and I had a few furry study buddies for the afternoon. The reason I'm not giving it a lot of stars is that the food was pretty bad. I got a soup and it was served almost cold and tasteless... They were nice enough to replace the bread with a side salad at no extra charge but it didn't taste of much either.  The coffee and service was super friendly and good but I'd not eat there again. However if you're just going to study, they won't bother you if you stay awhile and it's pretty comfy surroundings. My friend got a pie and didn't care for it either so maybe they can up the food a bit to meet the rest of the standards of the place because it's a really cool little spot.

EhT9M0XJoSvnw7XF58AaFg.text: I'll let you in on a secret- you don't have to actually own a bike in order to come here and enjoy the coffee and the ambiance. Crazy, right?The iced coffee is practically divine. It's a bit tight if you're sitting at the middle tables, but the tables themselves are plenty big and if you're lucky you'll get to smell the most deliciously smelly of pies as they zoom from the kitchens.

l3Wz8aJ7cdVKZR50y2zNfw.text: Not a biker, only come here for the cafe. The food is just alright and the coffee is mediocre compare to dozens of other espresso shops around the area. The staff are not that friendly and frequently overworked - resulting the toilet being dirty or decrease in coffee quality.Why I'm coming back: ample seating and late closing time. 10pm is amazing for a night-owl like me.

JZtgX7j-eu0b8SMnJWJr0A.text: The coffee is good, but expensive and the service none too friendly. I came here to work, but they turn off wifi from 12 to 2 to make room for their lunch crowd. The food was good as well, and they get extra points for having vegan options. I like the concept of a cycle cafe, but I was not at all comfortable with the atmosphere here. I dropped plenty of cash when I was here, but still felt like I wasn't welcome with my laptop. Disappointing.

6U_RS_eOiZSZixbCPUxRXw.text: Had a bacon and egg muffin for take away.First of all it wasn't cheap at almost 5 quid (if I remember correctly). Also the bacon is American style - burnt to a crisp. I'm an English bacon guy. Also the muffin wasn't all that great in its own right. Soaked with yolk it was better but still no wow factor.In short this looks more like a gimmick than an honestly good cafe.

ua5UlfrxpidooheLItblug.text: To begin with.. I love the name! First thought it's a bike repair shop only, but entering it .. you'll be like WoW this is a super cozy café, too!Delicious sandwiches, quiches and hot drinks are waiting for you.Prices are very london style, but I got over that shock already..Nice atmosphere in a very special place!

Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Teaaaaa Time
Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Chorizo Sandwich

BmrCH9vmv_xPvObXzhdn1g.text: "Look mum, no hands". I still remember shouting that to my mum when I was 11 and her shrieked reply of "Bethany, watch what you're doing!" - the look of horror on her face.Today however, no horror, no screaming but instead a unusual yet intriguing bike shop/cafe which has become infamous throughout Europe. We walked in and grabbed a table. We were here for a brainstorming session so we were looking for a relaxed work/lunch space and this place definitely fitted the bill! As you enter you can't help but stare at the different bikes on the roof and the quirky but simple interior. The food menu is varied and quite particular (in regards to salads - no fruit on my salad please) but the spread is vast and presented well on top of the counter and in the fridge.The woman behind the counter was slightly grumpy if I'm honest and not very warming but I ordered my food and grabbed a seat!I opted for the avocado/guacamole and wild mushroom on toast and the mushroom frittata topped with chorizo. I was hungry. The avocado and wild mushrooms on toast was truly delicious! There was a hint of lime running through the avocado and it complimented the mushrooms perfectly! As for the frittata, I liked it, I didn't love it - it became very samey very quickly and I found it slightly dull in flavour.  Overall though I had a truly pleasant experience at Look mum, no hands and really enjoyed our session there.OH and don't forget they have a bike shop for all you cycling enthusiasts out there!

Ndv3ruKOal2UKtVHTPDZ3g.text: This place is in Alex's list of great spots to have coffee and today, I had the chance to taste it myself. They have free wi-fi here, and I'm writing this on my laptop while taking little sips of sweetness. My mocca is very warm and creamy, but I can't wait for it to cool down until I drink. The place has a lovely interior that makes you feel comfy and relaxed. It is quiet and almost empty at such an early hour, but this way I can focus on work and enjoy my morning. I also tried their freshly baked croissant with butter and jam which gave me even more strength to start the week. Having this place in my area, I already know I'll be back soon.

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom

2UYHGZvlwITiUEbkXpg1jA.text: Loved this place!  - Whopper food (red velvet cake. Sweet mother)- Chocolate tea (not hot chocolate!)- Hotter staff- Quirky interior- Free wifi (except on lunchtimes)What else could ya want or need?!

9n4pXs_o2E4DpkWy0QZdVw.text: In my quest to find creative spaces to work, behold...Look Mum No Hands!This quirky little cafe-slash-bicycle supply shop gives new meaning to the term biker bar. With bicycles adorning its main window facing Old Street, to bike racks and benches out front, to the bicycle repair and supplies shop inside, it's hipster to the 10th power But I'm from San Francisco so we pretty much invented hipsters. Aside from your usual coffee-latte-chai selection, you can grub on salad, quiches and light snacks. I had a goat cheese quiche with salad that was light and tasty - with cherry tomatoes and sweet potatoes drizzled in vinaigrette. Order at the counter and they bring your order to you.When you're a freelancer like me, you'll appreciate what I believe to the BEST part:Outlets can be found along the couches, which is also the best place to prop open your laptop.Give me couch, a power outlet and some food and good luck trying to get rid of me!Side note: No wifi from 11-4 Saturday and Sunday and from 11-2 Monday to Friday.

7WHrTXeKbKGnqBJ5ubp_pQ.text: Pros: Tasty food, nice decor, good music, good beers and a great atmosphere!Cons: A little more expensive than I was expecting. One £ is a little misleading I think. Would definitely come back.

W4rPutqTkI1l6V78PtuIXA.text: Go for brekky or lunch, and order the salmon, avocado, scrambled eggs and toast. So so good! The matcha latte is perfection too.If you go for brunch, get there between 12-1pm to get a seat without waiting in line. There's plenty of seats inside and outside too but it does get quite busy after 1! You can also come here to get your wheels fixed or to stock up on quality cycle gear. This place is rad!

D0nDbIIh4_orwIux0bQRAA.text: Great coffee, certainly stronger than I'm used to in the U.S. I got a mocha and the flavor was smooth and delicious. The atmosphere is interesting with bikers constantly coming and going. It's definitely a place for hipsters to be. The outdoor area is very focused on the biking aspect while the inside provides ample seating and a warm spot to grab some breakfast.The menu is pretty standard for coffee shops, equivalent to that of Starbucks or Costa. I would definitely recommend for anyone looking for an off-beat cafe.

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Great coffee and a vibey atmosphere. Perfect for a morning pick me up before work.

EzJwlLMTz8hQLfW7V0PvbQ.text: "When bikes and coffee collide..." The cute name aside, this place is legit. I don't have a bike that needs fixing (or throbbing over) -- I'm too worried that I'll 1. get hit by a taxi, 2. get hit by a bus or 3. get stolen.  But I do love coffee and I do love sweet potato soup! A gal pal and I stopped in for a late Sunday lunch and enjoyed cold salad plates (this is a thing in London that I love -- salad plates, mixed all together and wonderful) -- green beans, noodles, all sorts of things. The sweet potato soup with corinader and coconut though? Out of this world -- hands needed, hands needed! Dig in. Counter service, a pretty laid back cafe. The din is minimal as folks hum over their laptops (free wifi abound). I actually do prefer the mellower vibe of Timberyard a few doors down, but "Look Mum No Hands!" is a pretty darn close second.

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Will need hands for this!

INQenivBIoQnSyzuI1bbNw.text: If you're looking to check out a cool new coffee shop, this is the perfect one to go to. It has a catchy name, doubles as a bike shop with cool hipster-y decorations, and has wi-fi (During peak hours, wi-fi is turned off - from 11-4 Saturday and Sunday and from 11-2 Monday to Friday). Wi-fi password is written on the till. The chai latte was one of the best that I've managed to get in London and that made me like this place right away. It had laid back vibe and I got work done easily in this atmosphere. I also tried their avocado toast with steak and it was really good. There's outlets along the walls where theres counters to work at and theres a couple of tables as well. They do host events sometimes; they started putting out "reserved" fliers and letting customers sitting at certain tables know that they would have to vacate those seats. They did this an hour in advance to the event, giving time to finish up or to move seats.

Qd_P7sEN7Yd51O-k7zI1dg.text: I popped in here for a breakfast meeting last week and was pleasantly surprised. I'd been told that as breakfast go, there are better choices locally, but the food here was good enough.I liked the idea of the black pudding-centric option, but decided instead on a smoked salmon and cream cheese, sesame seed bagel, and it was tasty!My pot of red bush tea was nice although the person behind the counter tried looked blankly at me until I called it by it's 'official' title, Rooibos - and then she tried to correct my pronunciation... I'm half South African, I know how to say Rooibos!Whilst we are talking about the staff, I found their lack of uniforms confusing. When I arrived there were a few staff members, or managers perhaps spread around the cafe on laptops, but I wasn't sure if they were patrons so asking to share a table (there weren't many free tables) was a bit shaky. I didn't realise they worked there until they kept wandering behind the counter.Overall not a bad breakfast, but I guess not owning a fixie, I didn't feel cool enough to sit in there.

dyIgPsPm5He7BT4p4_6HsA.text: Atmosphere : 5food: 3Total: 4LMNH is a a quirky little hipster cafe/bicycle supply ship to go to. Walking by it it stood out as a great place to grab a late breakfast. The atmosphere is seriously amazing.  Very chill. I sat outside on a wooden table looking out towards the road but in their beautiful looking courtyard. I caught great vibes from the place. The food on the other hand wasn't that great. I'm not a butter person, and most of my food just tasted like butter and the sourdough bread was soaked in butter.

If you are in the area then yes do visit, but I don't think you have to go out of your way to visit this place.

n7FWnvlHza0V0qd4ToG-Tg.text: This just about edges out Workshop Coffee to be the best in the area. Bright space and Internet clinches it - plus the quality of their phenomenal flat white never varies. Breakfast is excellent, although the one time I did eat in the evening it was actually awful... Not sure if that was a one off. The bicycle thing is legit, even though it might feel uber hipster. Just roll with it. On a final note, they also stock fantastic beer! The Kernel IPA is one of my favourites.

YjF-sRKcAgLnMnSkmG-8aQ.text: Friendly coffee place where hipsters gather. Also happens to be in my neighborhood. Serving square mile coffee and good eats by day and some nice craft beers by night it is a solid (if a little pricy) place to be. High quality ingredients are used though. Also received a £20 gift voucher to be used online, but when the item I wanted (square mile coffee beans) were sold out online, one o the owners just told me to come in to the store and get it. Also it to try some different roasts. That's service. I am not giving it five stars only because there are not many comfortable places to sit. That is what this place lacks-!Also I have never used their bike service or gone to any of their events. Overall highly recommended for coffee and hangout.

T2dRKRKPI4NqJM8Qs97q9w.text: The burger was surprisingly amazing for a bike shop ! Man this place is so hipster, Good coffee, good pastries, good food and probably good service for your bike. They sell their own accessories including Tour de France colored Look mum no hands branded underwear. I just love it. I usually rate the good places on Yelp with 4 stars so places like this can get 5! Love it.

5w9I8YB_v-v2pfyRm-CluA.text: I'm IN LOVE with this place. Every time I'm coming it is so great.The best place in London to work with your laptop / study / chill with friends / go on a date / have a coffee.Awesome.

HYoFNk-G9udLQOPPCgTxXA.text: LMNH is my go-to coffee shop and study spot. While I'm not a bike owner, this place is slowly convincing me I might just need to join the London bike community soon. Recommendations include their Matcha latte, teas, and their salmon breakfast. The staff is always friendly and the space is well lit and ideal for brainstorming.

bxeaba6qaaHWZFPCK0iTYw.text: Happy, friendly place for coffee and cake or a full-on breakfast or lunch. If you're a casual visitor you'll love it - but if you're a cyclist you'll love it even more

aIe1DoSSitlpVclY5z-j-Q.text: Idiotic policy, you can't even put your laptop onto a table. A table which you have bought food/drinks to they shout at you for putting a laptop there. I can go to literally any restaurant or coffee shop in London and I'd get better service.If this were another coffee shop I wouldn't care, but given that this place calls itself a work place you would expect that they put productivity at the forefront. Clearly this "work space" is for those whose "work" consists of updating tumblr or instagram pages and ruining Wikipedia entries. If you have anything meaningful you hope to accomplish here look elsewhere. If you don't believe me about this barbaric policy of no laptops on tables, I have included a photo to prove this lunacy.

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom

xKwTJUH9mgBPj_ptxb40kw.text: 3.5 stars. Sadly didnt get the chance to try any of the food, but the flat white was just okay. What I really loved about his place is the atmosphere and plenty of couch seating with a lot of outlets. Laptops arent allowed on the tables (to avoid freeriders) and they claim that they can turn the wifi off during extremely busy lunch hours, but they didn't on the day I was there. Would still drop by if I am in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom

-fwgfYYmMAIj8fsIyiwAgA.text: Concept Cafe for CyclistsAs a cyclist I was recommended this place by a friend and decided to visit on a Sunday morning. It is a vibrant cafe which has a good selection of breakfast. A comfortable seating area just for diners and a space by the window for the laptop brigade. The latter can happily type away sitting on their stools looking out at the hustle of the street. It also provides a workshop that fixes your bike while you have your meal. The first thing you notice is the cycling related items including the ancient bicycles that are arranged at the front of the cafe. Next the funky music hits you. If you like funk, like me, you will be chilled for the rest of the stay. The staff, and their were lots of them on a Sunday morning,  were polite and quick to get the order down. I had the Toast with avocado, salad and poached egg. Healthy and well made. I also ordered a latte which was a bit too milky for my taste. I sat down, enjoyed my breakfast, and planned where to hit next on this free Sunday morning.   This is an excellent spot to chill and I cannot recommend it more to the cycling loners out there.

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Enjoying the poached egg with avocado. The music makes this place very special.

0Nn8AXuHYU9hzhxGNtWQCA.text: This place was fantastic. I was looking for a cool, unique local place that wasn't super touristy where is could sit and get some serious coursework done for a few hours. This was a great fit, they have a wall full of outlets set up bar style and in the back is a single seating area that's cozier than just a desk style. Thy had a great atmosphere which was a little loud but nothing that headphones couldn't fix. They played stellar music too and had good coffee drinks. They also had a whole eating area for people seated at tables which made it a great lunch place, although I didn't get to try the food.Overall great experience and I recommend it to study by oneself or grab lunch or dinner with a group.

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. This is the view from the back seating against the far wall

3ppIbg-iaOqK5SsujkIV4A.text: Loved this place! It's so trendy and cute! It's a pretty large space inside and also has outdoor seating. It's also part bike shop which is where it gets its name! I went with my roommate and the food was pretty good although it's a little on the pricier side. I got the passion fruit smoothie and it was DELICIOUS! My favorite part of the cafe and I can't stop thinking about going back for another one!The decor is also really cute and it has a great atmosphere and vibe. It definitely has an instagrammable wall and whatnot, too! They had a pretty cool staff and good customer service, as well. I would definitely recommend this cafe!

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Cute wall right outside!

Rag0T9osz5394xpNM12Xfw.text: I live around the corner and this spot never disappoints. Fresh and full plates of eggs or avo toast or a punchy juice, I can always count on a seat at the counter or in the mosh pit. The scene is vibrant w the bike shop adj, I can't wait to enjoy a seat at the picnic tables come spring. I was a cyclist in my former life (Pre mummy) and the energy here is infectious. Love.

uH3Qu6hMHAOP-6OWaYNN0Q.text: Nice interior, but the coffee is not very good and rather lukewarm. Server also spilled it all over the table when he brought it to me. It's a cool place, but there are better options around.

UA_M8kDmcxk8I11iCtZnPw.text: Super chill place with great personality. A bike shop and a cafe, who knew? There are many tables inside but in the summer months, opting to sit out on the patio or even street side is a great choice. Service is friendly and accommodating. What I love about this place is their green tea latte, or should I say, matcha latte. They serve it unsweetened (which is difficult to come by these days). Their steamed whole milk with thick matcha powder make for an exceptionally strong and hearty green tea latte. May just become addicted to these! They offer a variety of sweet treats at the counter as well, your standard croissants, pastries, and cake slices. Check out the rainbow layered pride cake photo. A work of art, and amazing cream cheese frosting.

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Green tea latte, no sugar
Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Pride cake
Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Pride cake slice!

ebGnxz16ziWkiIoe-BZoPg.text: Absolutely great coffee shop/ cafe. Their new vegetarian menu is wonderful. I came here for brunch and will definitely be back. The tables are very close together but even when it's full it didn't feel too crowded. The noise level did get a little loud but not crazy. There were groups, kids, students working on laptops, everything you would expect from a cafe. A trendy place that lives up to its rating.

G_gBeylFWvsDlCfuBXWVSA.text: We came here twice on our holiday. This is a compliment as we set out to not visit any one place more than once. My partner's aunt who lives in the area had mentioned the place as they are dog friendly!This month(January 2018) they're trying an all vegetarian menu out and we were excited. As we are both vegetarians with inclinations towards trying to eat more vegan.  My BF ordered a cauliflower soup and it was delicious! It came with some flat bread on the side. And I don't even usually like cauliflower. When we came again it was the weekend and I was craving that soup! But they don't do soup on the weekends :( So BF had the mezze breakfast and I the toast.The vibe is chill and comfortable. They make a mean cappuccino, and the service is friendly and fast. I had ordered some toast which was cold on arrival and even though I had already eaten half of it they replaced the order for me with some warm hot bread. It's such a fun and nice place to sit in and hang out. Would go even for just the coffee and atmosphere. But as we're also excited about the vegetarian menu and they're looking for suggestions, make that cauliflower soup a regular, it's awesome! We would probably be here quite often if we lived nearby.

kBaWPU-wO53KAHpN3mvntQ.text: This place is the best. Delicious breakfast, friendly staff, bicycle fixing, good coffee... I even bought a bunch of merch. Walked out wearing a full Look Mum No Hands cyclist outfit and hat. Bought clothes for my nephew. He's gonna be decked the f*ck out in "Look Mum No Hands" gear.

c1aWe_Sngf8vieJeUUdcoQ.text: This is probably the ideal coffee shop to take my husband. While it's a nice (comfy, quiet, trendy) coffee shop to fulfill my needs, it also doubles as a bicycle repair shop to fulfill his needs. We rarely agree on coffee shops, but I think this might be the one place where we do.This place is located around the corner from my office. Every time that I have walked by there are always people working on laptops or informal business meetings occurring. Therefore, I came with the expectation that I may be able to get some work done. However, I think that I came at the wrong time (5pm) as this is when the coffee shop transforms into a pub. They serve beer & wine & coffee, which is great and all but the atmosphere was a bit more pubish in the evenings. This is my only complaint.On the other hand, the staff are very friendly. They have great customer service, which is not often found in London. The coffee is well coffee. All coffee tastes the same to me--maybe I'm a coffee moron. Overall, I'd come back, but I'd be aware of what time I came regarding work and noise level. It's great for a beer and conversation in the evening, but not so much work. I imagine that during the day it's the very opposite! :-)

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom

L2uXg1yufwSQtNCkZYOz_Q.text: Not a five because the service was awful! The barista (bearded dude in glasses) was extremely rude. The food was unfortunately pretty bad too. But the tea was hot and the ambience is awesome, plus they've got a bike shop BUILT INTO the coffee shop and free WiFi. A hipster paradise... or a paradise for people who love to ride bikes and hang our undisturbed in a medium-noise level cafe and take it all in.

wSLn8vuhfUbi8-Wlg18YuQ.text: Great place! Quirky and chilled out. Good reasonably priced food - had a nice smashed avo on toast there, and a decent coffee. The place is open late so you can stop by for a cheeky drink later in the evening.

-PF_YyCIyvRr4MkRf4grng.text: Food is good at this 2in1, bike and cafe shop. Low star rating after recent visit, for ridiculous prices/portions.Paid £3.50 for a meagre portion of the vegan pumpkin cake. I complained, and was told it was a thick slice. You decide, picture of fork hiding slice of cake.

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. 3.50 for a "thick" slice...
Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. 3.50 for a "thick" slice...

p_t1x5LzW-WwZopLa5ZD6w.text: Nice place for cyclism lovers! Good salads : green lentils, mozzarella, rucola, cherry tomatoes,... (generous portions!) and desserts (cakes, pastel de nata, etc.)Screen to watch races Service a bit chaotic, friendly staff though

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Bicycles on display

Kf3BhKdabsu94tNO3QD7yw.text: Very cute place with great breakfast and friendly staff. I really like the concept of the café/biker store which works very well. I had the avocado toast and toast with cream cheese. Both were delicious.

wFlI6ax4MGtIVC4XJW2fOA.text: This bicycle store/cafe/workshop is really amazing!The brownie I tasted was delicious. And you can sitt inside for several hours with just exploring the whole interior. In every corner they have something interesting. Even the toilet is worth a visit because of the interior. A lot of people worked there with their mac books (without free wifi from the store), while others  just met friends, had a chat, food or coffee. Outside there were some people working with their bicycles and others came just in for buing equipment for their bicycles.Very relaxed atmosphere, but quiet busy.

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. delicious vegan brownie
Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. bicycles all over the place
Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. very nice interior

frR2qU_J4bhyMBtFm6GOSg.text: A very very very cool bicycle and coffee/food/hangout cafe bar in the very very very cool district of Clerkenwell. I popped here a couple of times for coffees while staying and working close by and the beans were right on the money, served up by very friendly staff. The general vibe is rough, ready, relaxing - just a great place overall. Great music too. I did pop in on the last day of my visit to grab a very tasty organic sausage and avocado roll - lovely sausage and bread, just be careful if you're in a rush and want it to go as it probably took about 15 mins to come out. Not their fault - just a heads up if you're in a rush as everything is cooked fresh. I'm not massively into bikes so I'll let some other reviewers tell you about that side of the business ;-)

photos.caption: Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. Steak and cheese pie with beetroot salad
Photo of Look Mum No Hands! - London, United Kingdom. View from seat

o518lsrqygN-TqpEfgRy_A.text: Free WiFi, nice service and coffee and nice atmosphere. What else do you want? For me this is plenty enough to be happy.

l6X5mjZVxV_n8yRU5fuIgA.text: My roommate took me to this place and I have to say I love it. The cafe is pretty spacious for London and the coffee and food selection is great. The atmosphere is great which bicycles everywhere as the place also functions as a bike repair shop. It also has a little outside area, which is great when the London weather allows it. The cafe is pretty loud though, so I would not suggest it if you want to study or need to get work done, but for everything else I think its great. They place good music and the people there are very relaxed.

ctPo3KokwhtuPN16-vUiNQ.text: For a cyclist and a coffee addict, this place is a dream come true. Don't ever want to leave and a great place to pass time and use the free wifi!

GbWEbg4iR8xJWLVvVu0KmA.text: I don't have a bike :( But when I DO get a bike, I will ride it to 'Look Mum No Hands'!! Excellent coffee and a brilliant atmosphere. Thumbs up.

ZsYbMxk9VEM8cS3wxNjjYA.text: I found Look Mom online and made my way there in hopes that it would be a highlight of my trip. It didn't disappoint. Great coffee, snacks, a sort of bike museum, a shop of self-branded items (of which I bought a bunch) and a small repair shop. I wish we had anything like this back home in Munich.

9UBZeq7pP9aAUcVaqGVUOg.text: In theory, this place sounds like a great idea. I always walk past on my way to work intrigued by the concept - a bike workshop which also sells cakes and coffee and beer for those a little more thirsty. I always imagined that especially for cyclists going past it must be some sort of haven of a pit stop that they can't find in the nearby Benugos. A marriage that random holds some sort of appeal and I decided to try it out to see if I could make it a regular walking pit stop of my own. I went in, with no cash - this was my first error and second error. When I asked if they accepted card he said yes, but once I had ordered and they had started making my coffee he told me it was £5 minimum limit with no apology. Ok then. I ordered a croissant and canned drink which pushed it above the £5 minimum spend. Once I had paid he moved on to the next customer without comment. The "barrista" made my coffee in a mug - I had asked for take away. Once I had told him this with a heavy sigh he poured it into a take away mug, sloppily with cold milk. No sign of my croissant that I had been forced to buy. I told the man I had ordered it from and he just stared at the selection as if expecting me to take it away with no bag. When I asked him for one he looked like I had asked for something outrageous but with dragging feet went to get me one. Whilst his feet were dragging I saw their loyalty cards - wont have a need for these I thought to myself. The rest of my journey to work was spent trying to keep a lid on the take away coffee cup, the rim of which had been saturated in the milk he clumsily poured on. I got coffee all over me. For some this kind of attitude from the too cool for school staff and clientèle can't be too much of a turn off - it does seem irrationally popular. But if you, like me, appreciate the small things from cafes like warm coffee, customer service and not being ripped off then I'd stay on your bike.

OIcioCGtqko0pOGACQFAww.text: First time here some dude made my coffee and it was quite good next time the coffee was.. mediocre at best. The milk had separated and the coffee had been extracted badly. Either pay for better staff or give them some extra training if you are going to put them behind a marzocco with great beans. Oh and I love the bike theme, but I prefer beach cruisers not fixed wheel.

Vg4guYjKNRZI7G-jUk3dBg.text: Stumble upon it by chance as we were staying in a near by hotel. Went there for breakfast the porridge with banana and honey was very good the muesli was great. Nice ambience. My boyfriend, is a bike freak, loved it..

wNwGBNnV_tg3ZAMB5uM9rw.text: My wife and I have been coming here consistently since open in May/10. Great atmosphere; reasonable prices; good coffee (go for a flat white); quality hot chocolate; good selection of beers (I prefer Bath Ale selections); excellent and healthy food (try the pies!); free wifi; long hours. You don't need to be a cyclist. We take out-of-towners here to experience the London alternative vibe. A great mix of people, though mostly hip Guardian reader types (I'm the one with the Economist...). Look out for the hipster mums, dads and babies. Caveats: I'd prefer taps rather than just bottled beer. Sometimes the ales are chilled down too cold. Service can be spotty. I suspect their bike repairs/parts are not the cheapest, but again it's more convenient and pleasant than a typical bike shop.

KZxwJKJm9xRDhS0TE2-x3Q.text: this is great place to relax and do homework whilst drinking a beer. it's quiet and full of interesting people. go here if you have a paper due or a book to read, it's good vibes!

9whrUsYBGDrZNt4EB3quGw.text: Brilliant. One of my favourite places in London, they have decent coffee, tea and food (big portions - they cater for cyclists here). Importantly they have lots of space, which is well-designed, free wifi and don't mind people working.

GDmeyrNsOBbelTZCcWEc3g.text: Have you got a flat on your cycle and a craving for an espresso? You couldn't possibly find a better place to stop than here (even if you haven't got a bike)!Look Mum No Hands! is a Cafe/Bar/Cycle repair shop all rolled into one! That means they can serve you up one of the best cups of coffee I've had in the area while you sit back and enjoy the free wifi and even get your cycle fixed in the shop. There's a long bar along the window with outlets cleverly hidden underneath for laptops as well as tables and corners to lounge about in. If you're lucky enough to catch it on a sunny London day, they've also got a nice outside seating area with picnic tables. What's nice is that they haven't just slapped it together, it's got a nice polished look while still feeling cozy and relaxing. It's about time Clerkenwell got more of a taste of the east side charm.

icW1Pn8vRDol4EyFZjQ87Q.text: An amazing find in London, a cyclists/commuter's dream come true. Starting your day and need coffee? Stop here. Midway through your day and need lunch and more coffee? Stop here. Winding down your day and want a beer or glass of wine? Stop here.       You get my point. You actually don't need any of those reasons to stop here, other than the fact that this is one of London's newest best kept secrets. Its a coffee shop/ bar/ bike shop, so if your in the need for a new tube for your tire or some caffeine they will be able to get you fixed up. The layout is amazing inside there are plenty of places to sit and hook up your laptop, and then there is amazing patio area to enjoy London on a bright warm day. There is a bike rack in the back and some spots on the wall to lock up to.My recommendation is try everything. I don't think they have anything bad on the menu. If you are from the states, try Vedett, it's an amazing beer on the blonder side. And don't forget to pick up a shirt and cycling cap. Support mom and pop shops, spread the word.PS- If you taking the tube here, go to the Barbican Stop and its a short walk from there.

SLvqZc7VXrcWprN9tENZ8g.text: I can see what all the hype is about--big open cafe, cool music, food, adults and hipsters all sharing space, and a great place to rock up your laptop for the day with lots of open light.  I had a Seattle/San Francisco bit of deja vous.BUT I walked in dreaming of a great sandwich or a toastie oozing with cheese, so much to the demise of my dream, they don't have sandwiches (or hot breakfast).  They have pasties, croquettes, and a salad assortment.  So I was super-disappointed on the food choices.  I opted for the large salad plate, and although the salads were good and the plate was ample (the small would have been fine) I was left wanting and had spent a bit too much.  Coffee is just okay--there was a feeble attempt at latte art in my cup but with very big foam bubbles.

ltJKXvJ5gsAICLq7HsdnYw.text: This isn't simply a coffee joint that also doubles as a bike shop, it's a REALLY GOOD coffee joint that also doubles as a bike shop.  And with such a Pacific Northwest ambiance, are you really surprised?This is seriously the best mocha I've had since arriving in London.  It's not too sweet (Starbucks) and not too bitter (Costa).Javalicious.  I know several barista hipsters in San Francisco's Mission District who would weep tears of joy if they ever set foot in this place.

bTFCjr6zt-yDG0BjL0wK6A.text: I had wanted to go here as I am in the 'cycling world' and I found this out via Twitter a while ago, but never managed to get round to coming to this part of the woods until now.The food was excellent and fresh, although pricey, so we didn't have that much. The punters seemed to be mainly those who were students who wanted to the bicycle cafe as a library for their free wifi so they would be sitting around on their computer, being quiet for ages or nearby  office workers, sitting on their own looking bored.  When I was there, no one brought in their bike or went to the bicycle section which was a real shame.  The decor was great and it was really handy to have a bicycle shop nearby, and lots of nice bike goodies, though I didn't think the bike caps, though fun and retro, were any good on London's roads with poor driving. I think the bicycle cafe is in the wrong place, and it is by a horrible and polluting busy road,  it doesn't really encourage cyclists passing through, I think it needs to be in a proper cycling area, near cycle paths and not in a 'trendy lefty area' .  It just seems to attract mostly the wrong types of people. It could be really friendly and informal in the right setting.

U2-kIbzlqluPlWZSqBxR8Q.text: Meh. Yeah I'm not sold on Look Mum No Hands.. and I can't figure out why. I love the concept, bike cafes are so hip right now, doncha know? And it is very cute, with its outdoor tables, wooden benches and gorgeous bikes displayed everywhere. And some of the staff are very sweet and friendly, one has sworn up and down to me that their ginger cake is the bestest. But others, well they are the proverbial Shoreditch twats, who should never, ever be working in customer service.  I'm afraid Look Mum may already be a victim of its own success and the nicer staff will give way to people with comical moustaches. One has the Hook, (mohammadi.ca/?itemid=388) I'm totally serious. But you know what, they have great food and plugs everywhere. Four stars for effort.

b46SMU31e4_En9Fo6TkavA.text: They serves really good food and coffee. atmosphere is very relaxing.

IC2oLR_uMM0jHQ4aYZTyqQ.text: Get here early to snag a table as it gets crowded. They usually have an OK selection of salads and cakes. The butternut squash soup is a must!

ukZYNGUiNSUTwQMs08TNjw.text: Perfect study spot.They play good music, have a nice food and drink selection(even some cool beers for a break!), have a HUGE number of electric sockets to charge things(big plus) and free wifi.Has a very cool bicycle vibe and it doubles as a bicycle repair shop. Very unique!

f6nvc3B3fyudNCPMynu6qA.text: CAFFEINE HIGH! Downed a Vietnamese coffee literally fifteen minutes before popping into this place...and now just finishing an iced Americano here at Look Mum No hands! So if I am biased in any way, blame it on the coffee! :)That being said, this place is wonderful! I love the laid-back vibe and the fact that they have created a very unique sense of place at this bicycle repair shop cum coffee shop. There is a long bar with stools facing the window so it's nice to come and just people watch. Also, a great place to study since it's not too loud. There is also an outdoor seating area, which I always find as a bonus when it comes to cafes. It is a tad pricey, if you ask me - considering my iced Americano and small slice of almond pound cake cost me close to 5 quid. But I wouldn't mind paying this for the good atmosphere. Cheers!

17_6EZtVPh34uhOIuXyBDg.text: Half cafe, half bike shop. It's a fun concept.  Be aware, the wifi is really horrible, and the pastry prices are astronomical.

37uwfb4GmUeVWtZZA-o4PA.text: What a great concept. All the cool kids usually hang out in bike shops so why not combine it in an unpretentious cafe setting with good food, treats, coffee and drinks..smart! A nice range of salads and some vegetarian pies, plus delicious Guinness cake for indulgences :) Lots of cute boys too, and free bike parking and locks.

gBhXe-6Cz9r_ZschmMU0mA.text: I loved the big tables and free wifi. My new "it" spot with my laptop and a hot hot cap. The staff are super friendly and the drinks and food are great! My fav are the muffins. Will try some other things as well. Thinking of heading there now! If your in the neighborhood, def give it a try !

9CQFYJjVCzsIly2UpiAdmw.text: Nice place but quit dirty, average food, wifi was not working properly, staff very nice and polite

-jYpheR8XFgY5VmzOw4ccA.text: really chill ambience, bikes and greens all over the place. nice espresso

rWp94k0BPlP-P8fz_Pfjjw.text: What took me so long to find this place????? I don't own or ride a bike (soon to change, thanks Boris), am quite a bit older than the average punter here and yet I have been back three times since I stumbled upon it . . . Was that only 3 days ago? I love:vibe, people, quirkiness, fact that it's a workshop, long opening hours, yummy pastry treats, yummy food, service with a smile Could be improved just a teensie weensie bit:Double macchiato (inconsistent - excellent one time, slightly off the next), speed of service I will, however, be introducing new punters to this little gem on Old street, and when I can't rustle up the company will be admiring the trendy young ones all on my own!

GVXdptyBzBR2sfJAPFO6aA.text: Great to have a cycling cafe in London. Incredibly busy though, partly due to the atmosphere and the free wifi. Coffee is good, as is the tea.

9qDeqNmCzAVtp8nfKl4E0Q.text: I fear if I give this place anything less than 4 stars, Thomas A will no longer be friends with me.That being said, I did enjoy this cafe. The free wi fi is AWESOME and the sheer number of plugs scattered throughout the seating area was refreshing from London's anti-plug movement. I had a caramel flapjack thing that was quite good and the staff were all completely courteous and nice. They also don't seem to care when we whip out our laptops and sit a while.Maybe I just need to visit more to get it to the 5th star? I'd go back without any qualms, maybe I just can't commit to 5 because I'd feel like I'm cheating on my own neighborhood cafe. Yeah, that's it. Whilest I will come back here again, it's just not got the feel of my own coffeeshop here in Camden.

bbVHdKzjuNQhloW_tiSj4g.text: Great space.Convenient location.Decent food.Okay coffee.Spotty WiFi.Service can be either cheerily super friendly or icily nonchalant - just depends on the individual. I'm ambivalent at best about LMNH. There are things that I really like about it and things that turn me off and now have me walking past for other coffee shops (I've even opted instead for the nearby Starbucks a few times). But it is a lovely joint with a cool vibe and a good place to meet up with friends.

uNwpfznMeqehNFR8QWIYXQ.text: Love this place. Really great coffees and tea. Also recommend the pie with salat. Awesome atmosphere. I love sitting at the bar, plug my laptop in (under the table) and work for a while.
